entry.title: Re: #COE MRAS Poor performance of home page loading
entry.content:
Dear @ericyu,

Check 1. SAP explicitly notes that FLP load time grows with the number of tiles/target mappings/catalogs/groups, and that the load sequence is largely synchronous so more content = longer wait. The slow request is often the PageSet call that fetches the tiles. Also, performance often improves after caches are warmed until a server-side change/upgrade invalidates caches again

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3260681

Check 2. When a user reports slowness, capture the same artifacts every time so you can compare before/after upgrades

  • Exact time window (include timezone) + tenant + user or at least a user type/role set
  • Browser + version (Chrome/Edge), device, and whether they were on corporate network/VPN/home
  • HAR file while reproducing the slow logon/load SAP Support commonly uses HAR files to analyze performance and SAP provides step-by-step capture instructions for Chrome/Edge

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3290099

Check 3. Too much launchpad content per user

If the slow users have “heavy” launchpads, optimize what they load:

  • Reduce target mappings / tiles per assigned catalogs SAP mentions a guideline of < 100 target mappings per catalog for performance
  • Remove duplicated catalog assignments and redesign roles with more granularity. SAP points to using the Maintain Business Roles app it even mentions a Business Catalog Assignment Count to spot repetitions
  • If you still use legacy groups/home page behavior, consider settings like Show one group at a time and/or applying it globally via Manage Launchpad Settings
  • Also note SAP’s direction: Home Page / My Home are being replaced by Spaces & Pages so aligning to Spaces/Pages avoids dead-end tuning

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3260681

Check 4. Clear browser cache

After upgrades/UI5 updates, SAP notes browser cache can cause missing/overlapping tiles or loading issues and recommends cache cleaning in that context

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3000640

Check 5. Open an SAP incident

Open an incident when:

  • Many users are impacted, or
  • Slowness persists beyond the immediate post-upgrade window, or
  • HAR shows long server wait times (high TTFB) on core FLP requests

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: SAP CLM lease contract migration with APC and Accumul...
entry.content:
Good day @charlene2 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following reference.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/70747b45a7ab457b8eafbf4474a20d0c/b7138d1ebe19469a889137bc1abd3ae5.html?locale=en-US

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/d5699934e7004d048c4801b552f3b013/3c0dddd9424549fe9c46db30780c128c.html?locale=en-US

In summary, based on your description it seems the contract valuation triggered duplicate RoU and lease liability postings and also overwrote the useful life of the legacy asset despite using the ZMIG condition type.

That behaviour often happens when, either the statistical ZMIG condition is not isolated properly on the 31.12.2023 transition date, or when actual instalments are added with a start date before or on the transition date you chose.

That scenario gets triggered when:

  • The system interprets any non-statistical actual condition valid on or before the transaction date as if you have created a new lease and thereby it triggers standard IFRS 16 valuations.
  • The ZMIG condition is not enough to suppress valuation if other conditions override it.
  • The useful life of the asset gets overwritten based on lease term or contract instead of respecting the legacy values or conditions.

I suggest you:

  1. Reverse the valuation and this will remove posting of duplicate RoU and liability.
  2. Delete or deactivate the actual lease condition.
  3. Make sure you retain only the ZMIG condition that represents the NBV as statistical.
  4. Ensure that no actual payment condition is active before or on the 31.12.2023 transition date.
  5. And finally re-run the valuation and this will stop the system from posting new entries and avoid posting new RoU.

You should only add actual lease condition with a start date after the transition for example 01.01.2024 when transition and initial valuation is complete.

You can also review Contract and lease management through the SAP Help Portal.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Access Restrictions on Organizational Units in SAP Sales Cloud V2
entry.content:
Meet Aria, the regional sales admin at VeloCom, a mid-size telecom company that uses SAP Sales Cloud V2 to run its B2B sales operations.

VeloCom’s sales structure is spread across regions: North, South, and West. Each region has its own managers, front-line reps, service teams, and local processes. In the past, VeloCom struggled with one simple issue. Their admins either had too much access or too little.

If a North region admin wanted to maintain sales teams or update service org data, they had to rely on a central super admin. And the central admin had access to everything, even when they didn’t need it. Not ideal for agility or data governance.

Here’s where SAP Sales Cloud V2 changed the game.

The new way: Access restrictions by Organizational Unit

In V2, Organizational Unit access isn’t just a tag—it’s an actual control layer. Admins can now define:

  • Read access based on organizational unit

  • Write access based on organizational unit

And they can assign this access not just by role, but by who the user actually is in the hierarchy.
A person gets write access automatically if:

  • The organizational unit is assigned to them

  • They belong to that unit as an employee

  • They manage that unit

  • It falls under My Service Organizations

  • It falls under My Sales Organizations

  • Or the admin grants access to a specific OU directly

What this really means is that VeloCom can finally have local admins for North, South, and West without giving them the keys to the whole system.

Back to the story

Aria, the regional admin for North, now has write access only to North’s sales and service units. She can update employee assignments, maintain team structures, adjust territories, and handle day-to-day admin tasks for her region.

But she can’t touch South or West.
She doesn’t see data she shouldn’t.
And she doesn’t need to wait for the global super admin anymore.

The global admin, Liam, is still there—he has unrestricted access—but now he doesn’t spend his days approving minor structural changes. Each region runs smoother, cleaner, and faster.

Why users should care

For end users, especially in decentralized organizations:

  • Local units get autonomy without losing governance.

  • Super admins reduce workload.

  • Data access becomes cleaner and more secure.

  • Organizational changes happen faster because approvals aren’t bottlenecked.

A quick example

A sales manager in the North region wants to create a new sub-unit for an enterprise account team. Aria has write access to all North OUs. She creates the sub-unit, assigns employees, and adjusts access—without waiting for Liam, without touching anything outside North.

V2 respects the structure, mirrors the real organization, and keeps control where it belongs.

The bottom line

SAP Sales Cloud V2’s Organizational Unit access restrictions bring real-world hierarchy into system governance. Teams stay focused, admins stay empowered, and large organizations finally get the balance of control and flexibility they’ve always wanted.

And for companies like VeloCom, that’s not just a feature. It’s momentum.

entry.title: Re: capacity scheduling table dispatch error: Order &1 is...
entry.content:
Hello @Alessandro20,

I ran into this error again (“Order &1 could not be scheduled due to a technical error”) and after checking all the master data (Work Center, Shifts, Routing, Production Versions), I identified that the issue was caused by an order quantity that resulted in a very low capacity requirement (0.020 HR).

When I increased the order quantity, the capacity requirement increased to 0.180 HR, and the error disappeared.

Please check whether your order is not consuming an excessively low capacity quantity.

entry.title: What It Really Takes to Get Real-Time Sales Intelligence from SAP Sales Cloud V2 to Snowflake
entry.content:
I went into this project with one goal in mind: could we get real-time, analytics-ready sales data from SAP Sales Cloud V2 into Snowflake without building a complicated pipeline? I wanted a setup where real time data of leads, opportunities all flowed into one place, instantly usable for insights.

Turns out, the answer was yes. And the journey was smoother than expected.

How it all started

The first breakthrough came when we connected the SAP Sales Cloud V2 APIs. The Leads API, Opportunities API and event notifications slipped into AWS API Gateway and Lambda with almost no friction. It felt surprisingly straightforward for an enterprise system.

Once the events reached Lambda, the transformation and routing logic handled everything automatically. Snowpipe picked up the output and loaded the data into Snowflake without any scheduling or orchestration. The result was a near real-time stream of sales updates flowing end to end.

When the data reached Snowflake

This was the moment it all clicked. Snowflake handled the incoming JSON beautifully. No complex modeling. No schema wrestling. The semi-structured support worked exactly as promised, which meant we could start shaping the tables almost immediately.

With unified tables in place, the bigger picture finally emerged. We could see the entire sales funnel in one view: lead quality, opportunity progress, pipeline movement, conversion trends. And because everything sat in Snowflake, every analysis option was instantly available. SQL, Python, Snowpark ML and even Cortex AI for summarizing notes or spotting anomalies.

Insights weren’t a separate phase anymore. They came as soon as the data landed.

A small note on enrichment

One thing that required extra computation was enriching transactional data with master data. For example, getting the industry of an account meant pulling additional account details. It's simple enough, but something teams should plan for since it adds processing overhead.

What the final setup delivered

How it looks like in Snowflake 

By the end, the architecture felt clean, fast and ready for production.

SAP Sales Cloud V2 sent a steady stream of APIs and events. API Gateway secured the entry point. Lambda handled transformation at scale. Snowpipe pushed data directly into Snowflake. And Snowflake unified everything, powered analytics, ran ML models and supported AI-driven summaries.

In short, the entire sales dataset finally lived in one place, updated in near real time and ready for predictive scoring, segmentation and deeper analysis.

The four big takeaways

Here’s what the project proved:

  1. The integration pattern is solid and repeatable.

  2. Real-time data flow from SAP Sales Cloud V2 is absolutely achievable.

  3. Once data hits Snowflake, analytics and ML unlock instantly.

  4. The whole architecture is scalable, secure and ready for enterprise use.

entry.title: Migrating XSLT mappings from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
This blog post is part of the series Master Blog: SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration – Tool and Guidance exploring how to migrate various integration patterns from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite using the Migration Tool. In this blog, we will explore the migration process of XSLT mappings.   

While SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration supports XSLT mappings, you may encounter subtle yet impactful differences when migrating XSLT-based mappings from SAP Process Orchestration (PO). This post outlines the main variations between both environments, explains typical runtime issues, and provides practical guidance for smooth adaptation.

 

XSLT Processor Differences 

The XSLT processor behind Cloud Integration is Saxon EE 9.9.1.6 (as of November 2025 – see this Blog for details on verifying the processor version) while SAP Process Orchestration next to its default allowed the import and use of other processors. 

While these differences should not usually cause major compatibility problems, certain manual adjustments after the tool-assisted migration might be required to deploy or execute mappings successfully. In particular, there are variations in how standard XSLT functions handle data types, how Java classes are used within XSLT code and how other stylesheets are included. 

 

Data Type Handling in XSLT Functions 

SAP Process Orchestration tends to be more lenient regarding data type usage in standard XSLT functions. Cloud Integration, on the other hand, applies stricter type validation during compilation and runtime. 

Example 1: Using xsl:sort with Data Types 

The xsl:sort function sorts data based on specified criteria: 

<xsl:sort select="data" data-type="text"/> 

The allowed data types for this function are "text" and "number". On SAP Process Orchestration, the following syntax works without error: 

<xsl:sort select="DATES" order="ascending" data-type="xsd:Date"/> 

However, in Cloud Integration this causes a runtime error: 

Adjusting the data-type accordingly to text or number solves this issue. However, one needs to pay attention to the effects this might have on the format and thus the rest of the stylesheet execution. 

 

Example 2: Using format-number() with non-numeric inputs 

On SAP Process Orchestration, the following syntax works without error: 

<xsl:value-of select="format-number(substring(data, 0, 3), '0.00')"/> 

In Cloud Integration, this causes a compilation error during runtime: 

The issue arises because format-number() requires a numeric input, while substring() returns a string. 
To resolve this, explicitly convert the substring to a number: 

<xsl:value-of select="format-number(number(substring(data, 0, 3)), '0.00')"/> 

Please note that if a global number format is defined, this conversion might affect the formatting of the substring according to that global setting. 

 

Using Java Classes in XSLT 

XSLT mappings sometimes rely on custom Java classes to extend the functionality of native XSLT functions, a common practice in integration projects where XSLT offered fewer built-in capabilities.  

During migration, you may encounter Java classes ranging from simple helpers (e.g., string or date transformations, counters) to more complex ones (e.g., document loaders, RFC calls, or value mapping lookups). While some advanced use cases may require redesign or alternative approaches, simpler helper classes can still be used in Cloud Integration. 

Step 1: Uploading the Java Classes 

Upload the Java classes as a JAR file and add them to the iFlow’s References (using the Archive option). 

If the java classes are contained in the same Imported Archive (IA) as the XSLT using them on PO, the migration tool will automatically import them as it imports the entire IA during the migration process. However, if the java classes are in a separate IA, this needs to be done manually post tool migration. 

Please note that the JAR file must be added as a local resource into the iFlow. Currently it’s not possible to use as a reusable artifact. 

Step 2: Adjusting XSLT Syntax 

 

  1. Namespace Declarations 

SAP Process Orchestration allows multiple styles for Java namespace declarations, while Saxon (the processor in Cloud Integration) supports only one format. 

  1. a) Inline Declaration 

xmlns:java="http://xml.apache.org/xslt/java" 

<xsl:variable name="date" select="java:com.edi.xslthelper.DateTransform.GetDate(data)"/> 

  1. b) Namespace Declaration with Class Path 

xmlns:date="java:com.edi.xslthelper.DateTransform" 

<xsl:variable name="date" select="date:GetDate(data)"/> 

In Cloud Integration, only the second option (namespace declaration with class path) is supported. Therefore, all Java class calls must be manually adapted accordingly. 

 

  1. Type Handling in Java Class Calls 

Just like native XSLT functions, Java class calls in Cloud Integration require explicit type consistency. For example: 

<xsl:variable name="__function4" select="variable:setValue($var,'Name',string(number(data)))"/> 

If a Java class expects a string, the input must be explicitly converted. On SAP Process Orchestration, the same code might work without this conversion. 

In one specific migration case, a Java method required an integer input — here, neither round() nor number() worked, but the XSLT function xs:integer() was necessary. 
 

Please note that compilation errors such as “Errors were reported during stylesheet compilation” are often related to incorrect data types. Explicitly converting inputs usually resolves these issues. 

 

References to other stylesheets within the XSLT 

XSLT code from different stylesheets can be used in an XSLT mapping using the include function: 

<xsl:include href="Stylesheet2.xsl"/> 

The included stylesheet needs to be added manually as a reference to the iflow: 

On Cloud Integration, no folder structures are supported so if the IA on PO had a nested folder structure containing the stylesheets, make sure to upload them individually and remove the path in the include function of your original stylesheet like our example above. 

 

Recommendations for Successful Migration 

To ensure smooth execution of XSLT mappings in Cloud Integration: 

  • Always verify and explicitly define correct data types. 
  • Adapt namespace declarations for all Java class calls. 
  • Adapt the include of additional stylesheets. 
  • Upload all necessary additional components (jar files, stylesheets). 
  • Test mappings individually after migration to detect type-related issues early. 
  • Simplify or refactor complex Java-dependent logic where possible. 

Following these guidelines helps prevent runtime errors and ensures stable, predictable execution after migration. 

 

Conclusion and Next Steps 

Migrating XSLT mappings from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite requires close attention to how the underlying XSLT processor interprets data types and Java extensions. 
While most mappings migrate seamlessly, subtle differences, particularly in data type handling, namespace declarations, and custom Java integrations, may lead to compilation or runtime issues if not adjusted. 

Stay tuned for the next part of this series, where we’ll continue our deep dive into migration patterns and modernization best practices in SAP Integration Suite, including insights on content-based routing, custom code handling, and error management.

entry.title: SAP Business One for HANA Client Hangs Permanently on Loading Screen After Successful Credentials
entry.content:
1. System Environment

  • SAP B1 Version:

    SAP B1 10.0 VERSION for HANA & PL 02

  • Database: SAP HANA

    SAP HANA Enterprise Edition 2.0 SPS04 Rev 45 for B1

  • Deployment:

    On-Premise

2. Problem Description

After the user successfully enters credentials and selects the company database in the SAP Business One client, the client window opens but gets permanently stuck on the loading screen. The main application menu never appears.

  • No specific error message or timeout occurs; the process hangs indefinitely.

  • This issue affects all users and all client machines.

3. Steps to Reproduce

  1. Launch the SAP Business One client.

  2. Enter credentials and select the Company Database.

  3. Click OK.

  4. The application window opens and hangs on the loading screen indefinitely.

4. Detailed Troubleshooting Performed

We have executed the following checks, ruling out core database and server issues:

  • HANA Database Status: Verified that all core SAP HANA services (Indexserver, Nameserver, Daemon, etc.) are running and active (Green status). The relevant screenshot from the HANA Cockpit/Studio is attached.

  • B1 Service Health: Confirmed the License Manager Service, SLD Service, and B1iF/Service Layer are all running and restarted.

  • Server Load: Confirmed there is no unusual CPU or Memory utilization on either the HANA or B1 Application Server during the hang.

  • Add-On Bypass: We attempted to log in using the CTRL + SHIFT method to bypass Add-On initialization; the issue persists.

  • User/Role Check: The hang occurs for all users, including the B1 Superuser.

5. Conclusion & Request

The hang is likely occurring at the application layer during the B1 License validation, Cockpit loading, or interaction with an internal B1 service.

We require immediate support to resolve this issue.

Thank you for your urgent attention on this matter.

Best regards,

Sunil Patil

entry.title: Understanding Average Exception Aggregation in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Designing calculations is a core aspect of modeling in SAP Analytics Cloud. The platform offers a comprehensive set of functions, aggregations, and disaggregation techniques that allow modelers to implement business logic effectively. Within this toolbox, exception aggregation plays a key role by allowing modelers to control whether a measure is aggregated before or after formula calculations are applied. This blog focuses on the average-type exception aggregation, explains how each behaves,  and outlines the scenarios where they are most appropriate. 

There are four types of average exception aggregation, each defining a different way to select the members considered in the calculations.

Average

When to use: Choose “Average” when you want to include NULL and zero values in the calculation.

In SAP Analytics Cloud, NULL values can occur for several reasons:  

  • They may originate from imported data containing empty records.
  • More commonly, NULLs are created implicitly when another measure is booked for the same combination of dimension members. For example, if Measure A is unbooked for a given intersection (Date “2025-01”, Project “PRJ-001”) but Measure B is booked, SAC assigns a NULL to Measure A for that same combination of dimension members.
  • They can also arise in calculated measures, such as formulas that return NULL, or a restricted measure used in the story with a filter outside its restriction interval. For example, if a measure is restricted to 2025 but the table shows all years, the non-2025 years will return NULL.

Understanding this behavior is important because NULL values influence how averages are calculated. Under the “Average” exception aggregation, NULLs increase the count of members in the denominator, even though they do not contribute to the sum. As a result, the final average may differ from what is expected, particularly when measures follow different booking patterns.

NULL and UNBOOKED are not the same. UNBOOKED indicates an empty state, where no record exists. NULL, on the other hand, is a technical value used by SAP Analytics Cloud to represent missing values for a given record/dimension combination, such as when a record/row exists because another measure has a booked value for the same combination. This difference can be observed in the fact view under Model → Data Foundation: Unbooked rows are not shown at all, while NULL cells are explicitly displayed as (NULL).

Average excl. NULL

When to use: Choose “Average excl. NULL” when you want to exclude NULL values from the calculation.

This option ensures that only members with booked values contribute to the average. NULL values are ignored, preventing the booked state from another measure influencing the calculation.

Example

The following example illustrates how "Average" and "Average excl. NULL" produce different results. This scenario uses a simplified planning model in which Capacity Hours, Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. Null, 0), and Consumed Hours (Avg. excl. Null) measures are maintained for the same Project-Role combination. 

  • Capacity Hours represents the monthly staffing capacity available for the given project/role.
  • Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. Null, 0) shows the actual hours worked/booked and is aggregated using the “Average” exception aggregation.
  • Consumed Hours (Avg. excl. Null) shows the same underlying consumption data as Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. Null, 0) but is aggregated using “Average excl. NULL”.

Figure 1. Comparison of Consumed Hours aggregated with "Average" and "Average excl. NULL". February is counted under "Average" but excluded under "Average excl. NULL".

Observed results in Q1 (2025):

  • Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. Null, 0) divides the total hours from January and March by all three months in the horizon, including Feb (2025), where there is no activity.
  • Consumed Hours (Avg. excl. Null) divides the total by only the months with recorded hours, producing the expected results for this scenario.

Why the difference, and what do the empty values in Feb (2025) represent?

As shown in the screenshot below, taken from the planning model's Data Foundation, the empty cells for the Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. Null, 0) and Consumed Hours (Avg. excl. Null) are assigned with NULLs. This happens because Capacity Hours is booked for the same Project-Role-Period combination. As a result: 

  • Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. Null, 0) counts Feb (2025)
  • Consumed Hours (Avg. excl. Null) ignores Feb (2025)

Figure 2. Viewing NULL values in the Model → Data Foundation.

Which aggregation is correct?

Before deciding, we need to clarify the business intention for aggregating consumed hours:

  • Case A: exclude months with no activity
  • Case B: include months with no activity

Consumed Hours (Avg. excl. NULL) produces the correct result for Case A, where months without activity should be excluded.

Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. NULL, 0) may appear correct at first glance for Case B, but its result only aligns with expectations in isolated situations rather than consistently. To understand why, look at what happens when we remove Capacity Hours from February (2025). Removing this value also removes February from the display when the table is set to hide unbooked members. In this state, Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. NULL, 0) returns 240, which is the sum of the booked values from January and March divided by two. The key observation is that the Average type no longer considers February, simply because the record is unbooked rather than NULL. In other words, the same measure, the same dimension combination, and the same consumption pattern produce different results depending on whether the data state was NULL or unbooked.

Figure 3. Removing Capacity Hours from February converts the period from NULL to Unbooked. With no record present, "Average" no longer counts February.

Figure 4. Unbooked period disappears from display when Show Unbooked is turned off.

To fulfill Case B correctly and consistently, the appropriate configuration is not “Average” but “Average incl. Unbooked”. This ensures that all periods in the horizon are counted, regardless of whether they are booked, null, or unbooked. See the “Average incl. Unbooked” section of this blog post.

The use of “Average” (i.e., including Null, 0) should therefore be limited to scenarios where the effects of NULL are intentional and understood. When there is no such explicit use case, another type of average exception aggregation should be used.

Below are examples of cases where such dependencies are purposeful, and the presence of a booked measure determines whether a period should be counted in the average.

  • If a Subscription Fee is booked for a month, that month must be counted when computing averages such as Monthly API Calls or Active Subscription Usage, even if there is no usage.
  • The existence of a Promotion Price or Promotion Flag defines the eligibility of that period. Because the promotion was available to the market, that time window must be counted when calculating averages such as Monthly Sales.

Average excl. 0, NULL

When to use: Choose “Average excl. 0, NULL” when you want to exclude both zero and NULL values from the calculation.

In addition to excluding NULLs, this exception aggregation also skips members booked with a zero. This is helpful when zero should not serve as a valid observation. Typical examples include KPIs where zero indicates “no measurement taken,” rather than a real data point.

Average incl. Unbooked

When to use: Choose “Average incl. Unbooked” when you want the calculation also to consider Unbooked members. Compared to “Average”, this exception aggregation treats any absence of value the same, regardless of whether the cell is technically stored as NULL or is completely unbooked.

This behavior makes “Average incl. Unbooked” suitable for use cases such as period-based KPIs, where the entire time horizon matters. For example, when calculating an average headcount for a year, you may want the denominator to include all twelve months, not just the months where headcount was recorded.

Extending the Example 

To illustrate the behavior more clearly, let’s extend the previous scenario by adding:

  • Consumed Hours (Average incl. Unbooked)
  • A second project: PRJ-002

Both projects share the booked data pattern, except that PRJ-002 has no Capacity Hours in Feb (2025). Because no measure is booked at that intersection, Feb (2025) is fully Unbooked for PRJ-002.

Figure 5. Extending the example with PRJ-002 demonstrates the difference between NULL and Unbooked. "Average incl. Unbooked" counts all periods, while "Average" includes only periods with a NULL.

What the results show:

  • Consumed Hours (Avg. incl. Null) produces different Q1 averages between PRJ-001 and PRJ-002, even though the underlying booked hours are identical. The difference exists because NULL is counted, while Unbooked is not.
  • Consumed Hours (Average incl. Unbooked) returns identical Q1 averages across both projects, because the denominator counts all months regardless of whether they contain booked, NULL, or unbooked values.

"Average incl. Unbooked" exception aggregation is the correct choice for Case B (include months with no activity), while "Average" behaves correctly only if those empty periods happen to be represented in the model as NULL rather than unbooked.

Summary

Exception Aggregation in SAP Analytics Cloud is a powerful mechanism that determines how measures roll up across dimensions. While average-type exception aggregation appears simple, its handling of NULL, zero, and unbooked members can change the result in ways that are not always intended.

Use “Average” only when the inclusion of NULL values is intentional and aligned with the business logic. It should not be selected by default. In most planning and reporting scenarios, the other three average-types ("Average excl. NULL", "Average excl. 0, NULL", or "Average incl. Unbooked") provide the expected behavior for the use case. By evaluating how NULLs are generated, whether they should be included in the average, and whether empty periods represent inactivity or a true absence, modelers can choose the appropriate average-type and ensure that their KPIs return results that reflect the intended business logic and that users can trust.

entry.title: How to Learn and Get Certified with SAP HANA Calculation View Modeling
entry.content:
SAP HANA Cloud, and SAP HANA Platform (on-premise) is a very popular solution for data management, with its powerful in-memory technology and a data model that fits a variety of data categories, including spatial, graph, unstructured data, and many more.

Calculation Views are the recommended approach to reporting efficiently on SAP HANA data using models that you design with a graphical user interface. To get an introduction to SAP HANA Calculation Views, read Jan ZWICKEL’s blog.

So how can you become proficient in SAP HANA Calculation Views modeling?

Calculation View Modeling belongs to the role Data Engineer - SAP HANA. In addition to Calculation View Modeling, this role also involves knowledge of SAP HANA Data Provisioning using technologies such as SAP HANA Smart Data Access (SDA) and SAP HANA Smart Data Integration (SDI).

The following diagram shows the Data Engineer role responsibilities compared with the Data Analyst/Data Scientist role.

 SAP HANA Cloud or SAP HANA Platform (On-Premise)?

As you might know already, SAP HANA Cloud is the technology on which SAP invests heavily, so most of the innovation is made in the cloud version, so that is where you should start if you are a beginner so that you are learning the latest features. But we also maintain a curriculum for SAP HANA On-Premise.

Let's checkout the course offerings:

SAP HANA Cloud SAP HANA On-PremiseCourse Purpose
HC300 - Developing Data Models in SAP HANA CloudHA300 - SAP HANA ModelingCover SAP HANA Calculation Views with a comprehensive course that also covers the practical aspects of the HDI Deployment Infrastructure (accessing external data, etc.)
HAHC55 - Provisioning Data to SAP HANAHAHC55 - Provisioning Data to SAP HANADiscuss native provisioning techniques of SAP HANA (Cloud and On-Premise), and covers virtualization, data replication and data transformation

These courses offer solid, theoretical knowledge, illustrations, and are complemented by demos by an instructor (HA300 instructor-led training) or recorded demos (HA300 self-study, HC300 and HAHC55).

What if I want to practice?

Here again, we have you covered!

The HA300 course is offered as an instructor-led training where you can work through lots of exercises on a provided SAP system. The HC300 and HAHC55 courses have fully configured SAP Practice Systems available, where you can quickly spin-up your own system, or access an existing system (depending on type of course and role) where you can practice a using the similar exercises that we have in the instructor-lead class. To access SAP Practice Systems you need a subscription to the SAP learning portal : learning.sap.com).

Note:  for a course such as HC300, your system is generally accessible a couple of minutes after you enrolled.

Want to learn how to access practice systems? Just click below:

  • HC300 - Developing Data Models with SAP HANA Cloud 

Live Sessions

In addition to courses and practice systems, the SAP Learning portal offers live sessions that are useful to go keep learning, ask questions, deepen your knowledge on specific topics. These sessions are delivered by subject-matter-experts (SMEs), either from SAP Training, SAP Partners or other experts at SAP such as Product Managers.

The sessions come under five categories:

  • Get Started
  • Expert Deep Dive
  • What's New
  • Get Certified
  • Stay Certified

Some of the live sessions are available for free, some require a subscription. This is visible in the example below:

SAP HANA Cloud Live Session catalog sample on SAP Learning 

So, ready for the big jump?

When you feel prepared enough, it's time to take the certification exam.

On this topic, there is some news. SAP is moving its certification model towards practice-based exams which will replace traditional theoretical/knowledge-based exams (multi-choice questions), starting January 1st 2026. Some pilot exams are already available since the beginning of November 2025.

To conclude, we are looking forward to getting your feedback on these resources aimed at getting your level higher in the area of SAP HANA Cloud modeling. Please feel free to use this new community and connect with us and other learners. Also let us know about topics you would like to have covered in future live sessions, so that we can make our content even more suited to your needs.

Happy learning with SAP!
Alain

entry.title: SAP ABAP SDK for IBM watsonx v1.5.0 released
entry.content:
On December 5, 2025, IBM has released version 1.5.0 of its ABAP® Software Development Kit (SDK) for IBM® watsonx™ services. The watsonx.ai service can be used to train, validate, tune, and deploy foundation and machine learning models. The watsonx.ai Runtime is used to build, run and manage generative AI and machine learning applications with built-in performance and scalability. The ABAP SDK provides a class library that can be downloaded to SAP systems using abapGit and comes in two flavors:

  • ABAP SDK for IBM watsonx, using SAP NetWeaver for the SAP Business Suite running on SAP NetWeaver 7.50 or above and for the SAP S/4HANA on-premises edition.
  • ABAP SDK for IBM watsonx, using SAP BTP ABAP Environment for the SAP Business Technology Platform ABAP Environment.

Enhancements in this release include new watsonx.ai methods for the categories Notebooks and Notebook Versions. More information about the changes in version 1.5.0 can be found in the repositories in the MIGRATION-V1.5.0.md  migration document.

Detailed information on how to setup and use the SDK can be found in the README.md files of the GitHub repositories. The README.md files also provide two comprehensive examples to show how the supported services can be used. An even more elaborated article about how use watsonx services with the ABAP SDK can be found in Joachim Rese's blog article How to Bring Generative AI to Your ABAP Program Using the ABAP SDK for IBM watsonx.

entry.title: Use of DSEDIT tool to create entry in sql.ini file for Sybase ASE database
entry.content:
SAP Data Services installation stalls as the installer is unable to identify the CMS and Audit repositories.

Environment for this installation setup

  • Product - SAP Data Services 4.3 
  • Database - Sybase ASE 16.0
  • Operating system - Windows Server 2019 Standard

Initial investigation took us to the ODBC connections and it worked fine and successfully connected to the respective database repositories. However on deeper analysis, it was observed that for the backend Sybase ASE database the connection doesn’t utilizes the ODBC connectors, it requires a Sybase client to be installed on the application machine and the resulting sql.ini file needs to be updated with the entries for CMS and AUDIT repositories.

SAP Data Services or Business Intelligence installation on Sybase ASE database needs the following client to be installed on the application host

After the installation below shown "sql.ini" file is created which needs to be amended with the entries of the repositories required for connection.

 

The format for the entries are

[CMS]
master=TCP,<Host/IP_of_DataBase_Host>,<Port_of_DataBase>
query=TCP,<Host/IP_of_DataBase_Host>,<Port_of_DataBase>

[AUDIT]
master=<Host/IP_of_DataBase_Host>,<Port_of_DataBase>
query=TCP,<Host/IP_of_DataBase_Host>,<Port_of_DataBase>

 

Another way of updating the sql.ini file is to use the DSEDIT tool provided by the client.

Launch the tool with administrator access

Click Ok

Click on the ServerObject and select Add

Enter the name of the repository, this should be exactly the same which will be used in the installation, in this example “CMS”

Double click on the server address bar on the right and click on the add button

On the TCP protocol in the network address bar enter the hostname/IP address followed by the port number at which the Sybase ASE DB is reachable separated by a comma

Once the entry is added test the connection

Right click and select Ping Server

Click on Ping

A connect succeeded message will prove the connection is successfully established, and an entry will get created in the sql.ini file with right syntax and parameters.

Now the installer will identify the CMS and AUDIT database repositories

entry.title: Discovery Package: Test, Demo, and Development for SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
Many partners have asked for a systems for testing, demos, and development of cloud-exclusive innovations such as AI capabilities, and Joule in a private cloud environment. Therefore we expanded our portfolio by introducing the Test, Demo and Development for SAP Cloud ERP Private, Discovery Package.

The Cloud ERP Private Discovery Package 2025 Release will be launched on December 12, 2025.

It is currently available only to partners, with more information and the ordering process provided on the central landing page in the Partner Portal.
 

What is the SAP Cloud ERP Private Discovery Package?

The Discovery Package is the SAP Cloud ERP Private successor to the on-premise SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance. It provides a SAP Cloud ERP Private system with:

- SAP S/4HANA core scope
- pre-activated Best Practice content
- additional demo scenarios
- a rich collection of continuously updated demo guides
- the option to connect your BTP account for Joule services

You can adjust configurations as needed and unlock additional scope (e.g. via business functions) if the required software components are installed—fully documented as part of the offering. The system is ideal for use cases like Fit-to-Standard analyses, exploring and demonstrating Cloud Private innovations and adding custom configurations to showcase extensions.
The system includes multiple clients for the different use cases:
- Client 000 – SAP Reference Client
- Client 100 – Preconfigured demo scenarios
- Client 200 – Activate content yourself
- Client 400 – Compare Best Practices across localizations

Key Benefits

Build and showcase your SAP Cloud ERP Private solutions to customers in your own dedicated system
Use a pre-configured SAP Cloud ERP Private system to develop your own content and test and demo SAP Cloud ERP solutions to your customers.

Explore and tailor the system to your business needs
Use curated demo guides to walk through activated best practices and extend scenarios. Customize users, content, and processes freely. Replace the system anytime with the latest version.

Leverage ready-to-use content with AI and Joule integration
Benefit from activated best practices, enriched demo data, and evolving curated guides. Discover how embedded AI and Joule enhance business processes and decision-making.

Seamlessly integrate with your SAP BTP environment
Unlock the full potential of SAP Business AI and other SAP BTP services by connecting your system with your SAP BTP account.

Develop and extend with clean core principles
Support modern development workflows including GitHub integration, SAINT for add-ons, and side-by-side extensions via BTP. Maintain a clean core while innovating flexibly.

Launch quickly with self services in SAP for Me
Experience efficient service provisioning and management with SAP for Me. Stay agile Stay agile with a self-service approach that allows for direct action.

Some Specifics

Refer to the Getting Started Guide for detailed information.

System Access
From local computers, the TDD system can be accessed via HTTPS only:
- SAP WebGUI, SAP Fiori Launchpad, and other HTTPS-enabled UI components of S/4
- ABAP Development Tools (ADT) via HTTPS-enabled logon
This ensures secure connectivity and compliance with cloud security standards.

Development Scope
• Tooling:
- WebGUI-based transactions (e.g., SE38/SE80; no ABAP Debugger)
- ADT (including debugging view and more)
• Partners are responsible for transferring development artifacts (git-based CTS recommended).
• Add-on Assembly Kit is available but offered separately by ICC.
• SAP Notes and other non-OS-based patches can be applied with an entitled partner S-User.

Provisioning and Management with SAP for Me

Ordering is simple: Place your request via Partner Portal, and the system will appear in SAP for Me once the order is booked. Provisioning takes about 90 minutes. For security place your IP ranges and then the system is ready to use.

By default, we provision a Cloud Private system with the latest version, which will be Cloud ERP Private 2025 as of December 12.
If you already have the 2023 FPS03 version of the Discovery Package running, you can simply reprovision from the 2025 template in SAP for Me—no need to go through the ordering process again.
We release a new version with every Feature Pack Stack (FPS) or general release, and you can reprovision to newer versions under the same subscription. You can also run multiple subscriptions in parallel.

In SAP for Me, you can also trigger service requests such as:
- Restrict Access (mandatory)
- System Reboot
- System Reprovisioning
- System Backup (weekly backups included)
- System Restore from Backup
- Enable ABAP Namespace for Development

The Discovery Package will continue to evolve, with additional use cases and capabilities planned for future releases.

entry.title: Embedded Analytics for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 - List of Available Tables Reporting & Dashboard
entry.content:
SAP Sales & Service Cloud Version 2 (V2) introduces a modernized approach to analytics by embedding SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) directly into the platform. This integration provides powerful reporting and dashboard capabilities without relying on external tools, enabling real-time insights and advanced visualization options.

Note :
Embedded Analytics provided in SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 is based on the embedded edition of SAP Analytics Cloud (eSAC). It is not the full version of SAP Analytics Cloud and therefore offers a limited set of functionalities compared to the standalone SAC solution.

What is Embedded Analytics in V2?

Unlike previous versions, V2 does not have native analytics. Instead, it leverages SAP Analytics Cloud, embedded edition (eSAC) as the single analytics engine across SAP solutions. This ensures:

  • Unified reporting experience across Sales and Service processes.
  • Real-time data analysis using standard C4C data sources.
  • Advanced visualization options like charts, tables, KPIs, and interactive dashboards.

Key Features

  • Design Stories Workcenter for administrators to create dashboards.
  • Analysis Workcenter for end-users to view and interact with stories.
  • Role-based access for personalized reporting.
  • Calculated Columns & Filters for custom metrics.
  • Single Sign-On (SSO) for secure access to eSAC

Available Data Sources & Tables

Embedded SAC uses the same standard data sources as native Business Analytics in C4C. These include:

  • Opportunity Data (Forecast vs. Actuals)
  • Account & Contact Information
  • Activity & Interaction Logs
  • Service Tickets / Cases (Status, Escalation, Source Channels)
  • Sales Orders & Quotes
  • Lead Management Data
  • Product & Pricing Tables

Each data source can be extended with:

  • Filters (e.g., by region, status, time frame)
  • Calculated Columns (e.g., revenue variance, SLA compliance)
  • Aggregations for KPIs.

Reporting & Dashboard Capabilities

With embedded SAC, you can:

  • Build Stories combining charts, tables, and text.
  • Create Numeric Charts for KPIs like Open Tickets or Revenue.
  • Use Color Coding & Conditional Formatting for better insights.
  • Enable Drill-down Analysis for detailed exploration.
  • Share dashboards securely across teams

Benefits for Sales & Service Teams

  • Sales Managers can track pipeline health, forecast accuracy, and order conversion.
  • Service Managers can monitor ticket resolution times, escalation trends, and customer satisfaction.
  • Executives get consolidated dashboards for strategic decision-making.

entry.title: How to properly configure SAP CAP MCP Server so Codex can detect it?
entry.content:
I'm trying to configure Codex to detect and use the SAP CAP MCP Server, but Codex keeps saying that no MCP server is running, even though I can start it manually and see it listening on a port.

Here is what I tried so far:

mcp.json

{
"servers": {
"cds-mcp": {
"command": "npx",
"args": ["-y", "@cap-js/mcp-server"],
"env": {},
"type": "stdio"
}
},
"inputs": []
}

 

The SAP CAP MCP server appears to run correctly (screenshot attached), but Codex still reports:

config.toml (Codex)

[tools.mcp-server-cap]
type = "mcp"
command = "cds-mcp"
args = ["--port", "4005"]

 

Question

Has anyone managed to configure Codex with the CAP MCP server?
Is there something obvious I'm missing. Perhaps related to TCP vs STDIO mode or how Codex expects MCP servers to be declared?

Any help or working example would be greatly appreciated.

entry.content:

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following reference.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/93bd0b1e72ca4cbcbfb942d4497529f7/170565565a0f4b30873b6bb1b6e66b3d.html?locale=en-US

This blog provides some insights: Project Budget Availability Control Profile – Time Range

To summarise, your observations are correct. The current public cloud does not provide native EAC/ETC feature in Enterprise Projects nor does it do for a direct UI for manual initial budget.

The best practices I suggest is:

For EAC/ETC Calculation:

Use SAP Analytics Cloud or create a Custom CDS Views to compute and visualise the desired EAC/ETC metrics. These can include actuals, commitments and planned values.

For your Initial Budge Entry:

  • The standard approach is through CSV when you use the import Financial Plan Data app.

There is no supported User Interface method for manual entry but you may consider templates to simplify your process.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

Hi SAP Community,

We are currently designing our architecture using:

  • SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud as ERP and financial system

  • SAP BTP for integrations and workflow

One gap we are running into is native gift card / voucher functionality across this stack. Our requirement includes:

Any shared experience or recommendations would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you!

entry.title: Incorrect Decimal Conversion SD_SDOC_PRINT01
entry.content:
Hi,

we are experiencing an issue with decimal formatting in our SD forms for customers outside Germany. For example, a customer from the Netherlands should see "1.234,56" but instead receives the US format "1,234.56".

 

I traced the problem with SFP tracing and inspected the pdfDocument.xml inside the generated PDF. The file contains <locale>de_NL</locale>, which is an invalid locale combination. I suspect the system falls back to the en_US locale, which explains the US-style number formatting.

 

When I set ls_docparams-langu to 'N', pdfDocument.xml shows <locale>nl_NL</locale> and the decimal formatting on the PDF is correct. Note: ls_docparams-langu gets its value from gs_nast-spras.

I think I'm missing a tiny step to solve this but I don't know where to go from here now.

entry.title: RAP DETERMINATION handler METHOD stuck in Infinite recursive calls to itself because of MODIFY EML
entry.content:
Hello Gurus,

The issue we are facing is exactly the same as,

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/determination-on-save-infinite-loop-issue-rap/qaq-p/12784660

and unfortunately we had to go with the same workaround, which doesn't seems to be legit approach. And as mentioned over one of the comments there, I also have the same concern,

Details of the issue we are facing : 

Below 3 fields are part of the RAP BO we have,

In the Behavior Definition we have maintained a DETERMINATION for the OnHoldQuantity field changes as shown below,

// determination set_allocation_status on save { update; create; field Allocation_In_hand, status; }

  determination set_allocation_status on save { update; create; field OnHoldQuantity; }

And below is the Implementation of this DETERMINATION handler METHOD set_allocation_status.

It can be noted that as part of this MODIFY EML we are modifying only allocation_in_hand and status fields of the Entity.

But once the Execution Control reaches this MODIFY EML, again it calls back the DETERMINATION code which we have maintained for OnHoldQuantity field and this cycle continues indefinitely. 

Even though we fixed this issue as per the workaround mentioned in the referenced thread, buy making use of a Helper Class with a Static Attribute which acts as a flag for the MODIFY action executed at first place. 

But, this doesn't seem to be a legit workaround and rather I guess we need to have some Syntax addition using which we can tell the system that it should be executed only once.

Equally Strange is that even though the DETERMINATION is set for OnHoldQuantity field and in the MODIFY EML we are changing other fields still this DETERMINATION meant for OnHoldQuantity field is getting triggered.

If I am missing anything here, requesting to pour in your thoughts.

Helpful suggestions much appreciated.

Thanks,

Sijin

entry.title: Re: Adding Additional Fields in Decision Table of BRF+ Ap...
entry.content:
@Saswata89 Sorry I am two years late to the party, but  honestly, even at this point, I have to say SAP hasn't really gone out of the way when it comes to OPD and BRF+ to allow flexibility for customers to adjust output management as they want to. 

I went through the same motions and arrived at the same problem.

At least this is my solution to the problem. 

 

#1 I don't want to add implicit enhancements to the system BUT by adding a POST exit to the method IF_FDT_APPLICATION_SETTINGS~GET_CHANGEABILITY in class CL_APOC_BRF_SETTINGS I opened the OPD_V3_BILLING_DOCUMENT application for editing in the development system. This gives me much needed flexibility to add custom expressions and such. 

#2 Now I can go to brf+ , navigate to the OPD_V3_BILLING_DOCUMENT application and adjust the Procedure call PC_GET_TRANSIENT_DATA by using my custom wrapper class around CL_FDP_V3_BD_TRANS_DATA_HELPER class. The wrapper calls the same methods of CL_FPD_V3_BD_TRANS_DATA_HELPER but for GET_TRANSIENT_DATA_BRF method, I populate the extra fields I've added. 

Alternatively, if you don't want to make changes to the BRF+ application, you can add an implicit enhancement to the GET_TRANSIENT_DATA_BRF method. 

I have to ask SAP as well. Is this is the only way ? 

Why cannot SAP expose some of the nicer badis ES_APOC_UTILITY and ES_APOC_CONFIGURATION for customer use that may solve a lot of problems for us. 

Best Regards,
Tharindu W

entry.title: Re: Create a Document in /SAPSLL/LEGDOC table with updati...
entry.content:
Hi,

Why do you want to use a BAPI or FM to update the table?
The question is quite generic.
The /SAPSLL/LEGDOC (Customs Document: Documents) is used for Documents, e.g. Document Determination.

So it is filled, e.g. with Data Default for Customs Documents, or Documents from Determination Strategies (Measures).
If you want to extend some things with development, you can use Interface /SAPSLL/IF_EX_CUHD_PROP e.g. for items with Method ITEM_DATA_PROPOSE (Propose Item Data for Customs Shipment/Declaration)

I hope that helps.

SAP Global Trade Services

Configuring Essential Tasks in SAP Commerce Cloud via the Backoffice Administration Cockpit 

Who actually needs this course?

This beginner-level course is designed for business users and consultants who wish to build their foundational skills in SAP Commerce Cloud administration. This course is part of a dedicated learning series aimed at supporting business users and consultants throughout their SAP Commerce Cloud journey. Learning Objectives

After completing this course, learners will be able to to configure SAP Commerce Cloud by performing typical administrative tasks in the Backoffice Administration Cockpit. More specifically, the course consists of 5 units:

entry.title: Re: Transport a printer deletion
entry.content:
Hello,

You can delete output devices (printers) using a transport request. This is documented in 64337 - Transporting output devices (printers) - SAP for Me

Steps:

  1. Identify the Output Device

    • Go to transaction SPAD.
    • Note down the name of the output device you want to delete.

  2. Delete the Output Device

    • In SPAD, delete the printer from the system.

  3. Create a Transport Request

    • Go to transaction SE09.
    • Create a Workbench Transport Request.

  4. Add the Object Manually

    • Double-click your transport request.
    • Add the object with the following details:
      • Program ID: R3TR
      • Object Type: SPDV
      • Object Name: [Output Device Name]

  5. Release the Transport

    • When you release this transport and import it into the next system, the specified output device will be deleted there as well.

entry.title: SuccessFactors 2H 2025: Seamless Talent Data Transfer from Inactive to Active Employment
entry.content:
What’s New?

SAP SuccessFactors introduces a powerful enhancement via the new feature Transfer Individual Talent Data from Inactive to Active Employment:

"Transfer Individual Talent Data from Inactive to Active Employment"- This enhancement introduces a person-centric Manage Individual Talent Data Transfer capability, enabling administrators to seamlessly migrate an employee’s complete talent history in a single action from inactive to active employment. 

Key Highlights

The new functionality inaugurates an advanced functionality within SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals, facilitating the seamless migration of an individual’s complete historical talent data from an inactive employment record to their current active employment in a single, streamlined process. This ensures uninterrupted continuity of performance insights across employment transitions, thereby supporting holistic talent management and organizational agility.

Business Use Cases

When an employee permanently relocates to a host country, a new user ID is assigned to them. During this transition, the employee requires access to their talent data originally associated with their home country user ID. In such instances, administrators or HR personnel can facilitate the seamless transfer of the employee’s talent data from their inactive home country user ID to the newly active host country user ID, ensuring uninterrupted access to their complete talent history.

How to Configure

  1. You have enabled Employee Central to manage multiple employments.
  2. You have enabled at least one of these modules: Goal Management, Performance Management, 360 Reviews, Continuous Performance Management, Calibration, and Career Development.
  3. You have enabled the data transfer tool through Admin Center > Company System and Logo Settings > Enable Individual Talent Data Transfer from Inactive to Active Employment.
  4. You're recommended to configure employment differentiators, which helps you identify and select the correct source and target employments for data transfer.
  5. The subject person for data transfer should have at least one inactive employment and one active employment.
  6. To ensure the person's new employment and their stakeholders have the permission to access the transferred data, make sure module-specific permissions are correctly granted with right target population. For details, refer to the Guide topic in the Related Information section.

Role-Based Permission Pre-requisites

  1. With the Administrator Permissions --> Manage System Properties --> Company System and Logo Settings permission, you have enabled the data transfer tool through Admin Center --> Company System and Logo Settings --> Enable Individual Talent Data Transfer from Inactive to Active Employment.
  2. You have the Administrator Permissions --> Manage Individual Talent Data Transfer permission to use the tool.
  3. You have the User Permissions --> General User Permission --> User Search permission for the specified target population.
  4. You have the Administrator Permissions Manage Hires --> Include Inactive Employees in the search permission to select inactive employments as the source for data transfer.
  5. You have the permission to view the status, title, and assignmentDisplayHeader (if you've configured the fields in the data modal) under User Permissions Employee Data   Employee Profile.
  6. The subject person for data transfer should have at least one inactive employment and one active employment.

Why It Matters

This important enhancement of Person-centric talent data transfers benefit organizations by ensuring uninterrupted access to comprehensive employee performance histories across transitions, enhancing data accuracy, reducing administrative workload, supporting compliance, and fostering agile, informed talent management. This approach strengthens employee engagement and retention by maintaining a continuous, unified view of their development and achievements.

Take Action

The transfer of talent data from an inactive to an active user ID can be tailored to align with your organizational requirements, enabling enhanced process agility and significantly reducing administrative burden through this advanced feature.

Start configuring today and experience the difference!

 

SAP SuccessFactors Performance & Goals SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central 

SAP SuccessFactors HCM Core SAP SuccessFactors HCM Suite

entry.title: Definição de conta para Impostos a recuperar
entry.content:
Boa Tarde!

Estou com um caso em que na contabilização, o PIS, com crédito, a recuperar, vai para a conta de estoque corretamente.

Já o Cofins, com crédito, a recuperar, vai para a conta de Variação de Preço.

Pis = Creditando PIS e debitando Conta de Estoque.

Cofins = Creditando Cofins e debitando Conta de Variação de Preço.

Grato desde já!

entry.title: Re: F110 : payment not possible because of reported error
entry.content:
Olá

Pode ser alguns casos dentre eles:

  • Método de pagamento / house Bank incompatível ou ausente
    Mesmo com FBZP configurada, pode haver falta de combinação válida entre método de pagamento, banco conta bancária e moeda. Se essa combinação não existe, o sistema não consegue gerar o pagamento.
  • Ausência de método de pagamento válido para os documentos (fatura/fatura aberta)
    Se os itens a pagar (faturas, notas) não têm método de pagamento definido, mesmo que a FBZP esteja configurada, a proposta/pagamento pode falhar com erro genérico.
  • Configuração incorreta ou incompleta de “determinação automática de contas” (automatic account determination / GL accounts)
    Com novas company codes, talvez falte configuração de contas contábeis relevantes (GL accounts) para determinados eventos — sobretudo se há descontos, impostos retidos, ou transações especiais.
  • Itens bloqueados ou condições de seleção não atendidas
    Se há bloqueio no cadastro do fornecedor, na fatura, ou se os critérios da execução de pagamento (data, moeda, limites mínimos/máximos, etc.)
  • Limites de valor mínimo/máximo para a forma de pagamento configurada
    A definição de faixas de valor para métodos de pagamento pode impedir o pagamento de valores fora de faixa, e esse tipo de bloqueio às vezes não gera uma mensagem de erro clara.
  • Configuração obrigatória de campos mestre de fornecedor não preenchida
    Por exemplo: se na configuração da forma de pagamento for obrigatório endereço, banco, CEP, cidade, etc., e o fornecedor não tiver esses dados, a seleção falha.

entry.title: Month wise depreciation with Net book value and Remaining use ful life
entry.content:
I have asset RS. 100000

Depreciation should be calculated with netbook value and remaining useful life 4 years for each month seprately. Normally i saw system calculate depreciation year wise and then divide it 12.

I want to calculate as follow:

1st month: 100000 / (12 x 4 = 48 month) = 2083.33

2nd Month: NBV (100000-2083.33) = 97916.66 / (47 month) = 2083.33

3rd month: NBV (97916.66 - 2083.33) = 95833.33 / (46 Month) = 2083.33

4th Month: NBV (95833.33 - 2083.33) = 93749.97 / (45 Month) = 2083.33

 

So my requirement is that for each month, system should calculate not only netbook value but also remaining month wise, not year wise.

Thanks

entry.title: Entendiendo la Extensibilidad en SAP Cloud ERP: Parte 3
entry.content:
Como vimos en los primeros dos blogs Parte 1 y Parte 2, extender SAP Cloud ERP (o comúnmente llamado SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition), es muy importante para adaptarse a la necesidad específica de cada uno de tus clientes.

SAP Cloud ERP puede extenderse dentro de si misma, pero en esta parte final, abordaremos una de las formas óptimas de escalar tu solución y es, mediante el uso de la SAP Business Technology Platform o SAP BTP, mediante el diseño de aplicaciones Multi-tenant y multi-backend, para esto tenemos varios ejemplos dentro de los recursos oficiales de SAP, pero quiero mostrarles el que para mí, es el más relevante para quienes desean comenzar en SAP Cloud ERP y tienen ya prácticas en otro de nuestros productos, como SAP Business One o SAP Business ByDesign.

 

 

 

Proceso de desarrollo para un cliente a múltiples tenants y diferentes Back-ends

Empecemos análizando lo siguiente: en tu empresa tienen una necesidad clara y deciden desarrollar una aplicación específica para un cliente, para ello puedes crearla directamente In-App, usando por ejemplo Key-user o Developer Extensibility en Cloud ERP.

Como segundo análisis, quiero que revisemos lo que pasa, si te das cuenta que esa necesidad es la misma para otros usuarios, el camino entonces, es pensar en una solución multi-tenant, que de hecho puede ser desarrollada dentro de SAP Cloud ERP, usando por ejemplo la Multi-off Delivery o la Scalable Delivery.

Ahora como tercer análisis, ¿qué pasa si te das cuenta que esa aplicación no solo es útil para clientes de SAP Cloud ERP?, sino que tienes clientes de SAP Business One, SAP Business ByDesign, o incluso deseas poner la aplicación como standalone solution y permitir el acceso a clientes que no cuentan con una de nuestras ERPs. Allí se hace muy relevante escalar nuestra aplicación y usar la SAP BTP como centro de desarrollo y despliegue, nos referimos entonces a una aplicación Multi-tenant y Multi-backend o de ERP agnóstico.

 

 

Modelos Operacionales

 

Como partner puedes tener diferentes modelos operacionales, uno de ellos es el modelo “Customer Managed” donde los clientes gestionan directamente la implementación y el mantenimiento de las soluciones, con el apoyo técnico y consultoria del Partner.

Otro modelo es el “Partner SaaS Solutions”, donde el Partner desarrolla y gestiona aplicaciones de software como servicio (SaaS) en la nube, utilizando la plataforma SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). Este modelo permite a los Partners ofrecer soluciones escalables y compatibles con las actualizaciones de SAP ERP, proporcionando a los clientes acceso a aplicaciones avanzadas y servicios como inteligencia artificial y machine Learning.

 

 

Partner Reference App: el caso de uso

 

La BTP Partner Reference App es un modelo, que te permite crear aplicaciones directamente en la SAP BTP, diseñadas para ser compatibles con las actualizaciones de SAP Cloud ERP, lo cual deja como resultado: fácil integración y mantenimiento de la misma. Incluye ventajas de compatibilidad y eficiencia. El link general de esta aplicación se encuentra publicado en nuestro GitHub  (BTP Partner Reference App).

La BTP Partner Reference app, sigue el modelo de soluciones de Software como Servicio para nuestros Partners. Al estar alojada en la SAP BTP está clasificada como una Side-by-side Extension, este tipo de aplicaciones son operadas desde esta plataforma y cuentan con ciclo de vida propio, independiente del ERP que se use.

Esta aplicación es un imaginario de un Poetry Slam, donde el usuario debe imaginar que es un manager de eventos, quien organiza eventos de poesía, y usa la aplicación para planear y ejecutar los eventos, analizar los costos, comprar equipo, publicar los eventos, manejar las reservas, los visitantes y artistas.

 

Este modelo, sigue los estándares SAP, con un modelo centralizado de identidad y autenticación, un Launchpad común, navegación entre aplicaciones y una integración back-end segura. Tienes dos formas de acceder a esta aplicación y probarla por ti mismo: la primera es ir directamente y clonar el repositorio de Github, o seguir paso a paso desde el desarrollo inicial hasta el modelo final. Si sigues el segundo paso la guía te llevará a:

 

1.     Crear el Core: donde el foco es la lógica, los roles, los modelos y el contenido.

2.     Make it scale: allí entenderás como pasar de una solución para un cliente a una multi-tenant

3.     Connect: Integra la solución con tu ERP preferida

4.     Features: Agrega nuevas funcionalidades, añade servicios, integra con elementos de terceros.

 

 

Tipo de Aplicaciones que pueden seguir este modelo

Pero ¿Cómo saber qué tipo de aplicaciones pueden seguir este modelo?, aconsejamos este tipo de extensión cuando:

-    Son aplicaciones para un grupo separado de usuarios (Usuarios sin ERP)

-    Aplicaciones que deben tener proximidad a SAP BTP para el aprovechamiento de servicios como Machine Learning, AI entre otros.

-    Soluciones que deben ser integradas con diferentes ERPs y servicios en la nube.

 

 

Ventajas de este tipo de aplicaciones

¿Qué ventajas tienen este tipo de aplicaciones principalmente?

-    SAP standard para el desarrollo, experiencia de usuario y diseño

-    Mantener el Clean Core, que te permite acelerar la innovación y estar siempre al día con actualizaciones.

-    Incluir Herramientas de Inteligencia artificial en tus soluciones.

 

 

Partner Journeys posibles

Seguir este modelo de arquitectura, permite tener un diseño que apoye diferentes caminos como Partners:

-    Un Partner de SAP Cloud ERP, puede crear IP que extienda la solución

-    Un Partner Business One puede extender su negocio a SAP Cloud ERP

-    Un Partner ByD puede extender su solución e IP a SAP Cloud ERP

-    Un Service Partner, puede crear una solución escalable que por ejemplo provea a una gran compañía con servicios a múltiples departamentos y subsidiarias.

 

 

Integración con SAP Cloud ERP

 

 

Para la integración con SAP Cloud ERP, es importante configurar el SAP Cloud Identity Services, y en la BTP el acceso de Trust Management, los servicios de Destino, entre otros servicios necesarios. Por el lado de SAP Cloud ERP, se deben configurar todos los canales de comunicación, como Communication arrangement, Communication System, etc. , agregar la aplicación como un “custom tile” y poder acceder a ella. 

El diseño de esta aplicación permite la integración en dos lineas, la primera Front-end que le permite navegar a la Aplicación Poetry Slam Manager a los proyectos específicos conectados en SAP Cloud ERP, y la integración Back-end que permite crear un proyecto en SAP Cloud ERP y visualizarlo dentro de la aplicación side-by-side mediante OData APis con el uso del principio de propagación.

 

 

Extender tu aplicación

En la última versión de este ejemplo, también se muestra la opción de adaptar este tipo de aplicación para clientes específicos, ya que hemos visto que aunque sea una solución que resuelva un Problema de muchos clientes, cada cliente tiene sus propias necesidades y adaptarla también genera robustez en la solución.

Al ser una Cloud Application Programming model, o CAP, también se pueden extender:

-    Campos

-    Entidades

-    Aplicaciones Web

-    APIs

 

 

Alcance del mercado al diseñar Multi-tenancy y ERP Agnogstic

Al aprovechar el diseño multitenant y ERP agnogstic, como partner de SAP, puedes aumentar significativamente el alcance del mercado. Este tipo de diseño permite que una sola instancia de aplicación sirva a multiples tenants, lo que implica soluciones escalables y rentables a más clientes, con la posibilidad de compartir servicios y disminuir costos. Además el diseño agnóstico, asegura que la aplicación pueda ser fácilmente integrada a diferentes ERPs, no solo con los de SAP aumentando el atractivo de este tipo de aplicaciones y utilidad en diferentes entornos de clientes. Este enfoque mejora la penetración del mercado y abre oportunidades para entregar soluciones a más clientes independiente de la estructura ERP existente.

 

En estos tres blogs y en español :P, hemos recorrido las diversas opciones para extender SAP Cloud ERP, destacando la importancia y las diversas formas de adaptar esta solución a las necesidades de tus clientes. Espero que esta información haya sido útil y te haya proporcionado una visión clara de como escalar tus soluciones.

 

Me encantaría saber que te pareció esta serie, Gracias por leerme.

 

Síguenos via @SAP and #S4HANA o encuéntrame en LinkedIn -> @Monica_Pimiento 

 

Saludos querido mundo SAP Hipanoparlante.

Mónica Pimiento

entry.title: Building the Future of Supplier Growth
entry.content:
For many years, we've heard from our customers: suppliers want more options, more opportunities, and more value. We listened to your needs and got to work. In Q1 2025, we landed an incredible milestone: launching the SAP Business Network, promote subscription, a new, one-of-a-kind subscription service designed to help suppliers show up stronger on the network, get discovered by the right buyers, and ultimately grow their businesses. 

This year wasn’t just about releasing new features. It was about laying the foundation for a modern, AI-enabled supplier experience that gives every business, regardless of size or tech maturity, the opportunity to stand out. 

Why We Built These Capabilities 

Supplier expectations are changing. Buyers are sourcing more strategically, relying on richer product data, and seeking partners who can demonstrate trust and authenticity in a sea of competition. Meanwhile, suppliers want more visibility, more control over how they present themselves, and more insights into how buyers engage with their profiles. 

Across industries and geographies, we heard a consistent message: 

“Help us put our best foot forward and help us understand what buyers are looking for.” 

This is the inspiration behind the product investments we made this year. 

What We Launched in 2024 

To support suppliers in showcasing their value and building new and stronger buyer relationships, we introduced several new capabilities as part of the SAP Business Network, promote subscription: 

Verified Profiles 

A new verification layer helps suppliers build trust with potential buyers by confirming key business information. Verified profiles stand out visually and give buyers confidence in the data behind them. 

AI-Generated Product Content 

Suppliers can now instantly create polished, buyer-friendly catalog content using generative AI. This helps standardize quality, reduce time spent on manual content creation, and ensure products appear in more relevant searches. 

Performance Insights 

Suppliers now have access to analytics that reveal how buyers engage with their profiles and catalogs. These insights highlight what’s working, what buyers are viewing, and where suppliers can strengthen their presence. 

AI-Based Profile Suggestions 

To help suppliers continuously improve, we introduced smart recommendations that identify missing information, highlight optimization opportunities, and guide suppliers toward a more complete and compelling profile. 

Together, these capabilities represent a major step forward in helping suppliers elevate their digital presence within the network. 

What We Learned This Year 

Launching a new supplier-facing product across a global network is no small feat, and we learned a lot along the way. 

  1. Quality supplier data is more important than ever 

Across every industry, buyers are prioritizing complete, accurate, and trustworthy information. Suppliers who invest in higher-quality profiles and catalog content are better positioned for visibility. 

  1. AI is a game-changer, especially for smaller suppliers 

Many suppliers told us they struggle to create or maintain robust product content. AI-generated descriptions and automated suggestions help level the playing field, giving every business access to professional-grade catalog data. 

  1. Suppliers want transparency into how buyers find them 

Suppliers want to know whether their profile is attracting views, which products buyers are clicking on, and how they can show up more effectively. Performance insights provide this invaluable detail to suppliers in an organized dashboard. 

  1. Supplier discovery is only as strong as the data behind it 

The more complete the profile and network catalog, the better the match. Everyone’s time is limited these days. By providing more complete data, SAP Business Network Discovery can provide higher quality matches, saving everyone time and reducing effort spent sorting through irrelevant matches by surfacing more relevant opportunities. 

What’s Coming in 2025 

This year was about building a strong foundation. Next year will be about scaling and expanding it. 

In 2026, we’re focused on: 

  • Enhancing the network catalog and profile user experience 
  • Continuing to strengthen verification and trust signals across the network 
  • Making it easier for suppliers to differentiate themselves and connect with new buyers 
  • Increasing supplier exposure during buyer sourcing and selection 

Our vision remains clear: 

Help suppliers grow with better visibility, better data, and better tools. 

Looking Ahead 

2025 marked an important step forward in creating a more powerful, modern supplier experience. We’re proud of the progress made and even more excited for what’s ahead. 

Thank you to all the suppliers who partnered with us this year, shared feedback, and pushed us to innovate. This is just the beginning. In 2026, we’ll build on this foundation to unlock even more opportunities for suppliers across the network. 

Here’s to a year of growth and the groundwork for even more to come. 

Want to learn more?

If you're interested in learning more about how your business can grow on the network, contact us to schedule a 1:1 consultation with the Supplier Growth Team here or at suppliergrowth@sap.com.

To access more resources, including webinars, demos, blogs, and more, to help you get the most out of your account, check out our SAP Community page for suppliers.
